entry.title: Re: 3 Must-Know configuration setups in Variable Pay
entry.content:
Hi @Ritanshi9 

Did anything change as well on the Bonus Eligibile Earnings ?

If the answer to the above question is "no nothing changed" then try adding merge="false" (like you did for PayGrade) on the Basis field in your varpayemphistdata background then reimport and test.

If the answer to the above question "yes" then there is nothing you can do to pull only the latest paygrade. In that case you would need to do a custom config where you pull the paygrade at entry level (hence as of EC effective date of the varpay template) then send it down to an ALCF field.

 

All the best,

Xavier

entry.title: HowTo in SAP DM: A Step-by-Step Guide to 'Using List Type parameters in Data Collection'
entry.content:
Introduction:

You want to use the "List" type parameter in Data Collection.

Steps to follow:

  • Step1: Create a new "Data Field" of type "List" from "Manage Data Fields" application.
    • You can mark one of the Option as "Default".

  • Step2: Goto "Manage Data Collection" App and create a new Parameter in an existing or a new "Data Collection Group"
    • The parameter should be of type "List"
    • Additionally, provide the previously created data field eg. "COLOR", in the field "Data Field List"
    • Assign the DC group to the right object.

  • Step3: Launch the POD to perform data collection for list type parameter
    • The parameter is defaulted to the maintained default value in "Data Field" definition
    • You can choose to change the parameter value from the value list

 

Pro Tips:

  • Use the list type parameter when you have handful of options to be used as a list. Example Colors, Models. If you have hundreds and thousands of options, go for text type if possible.
  • The "Log DC" public api also now supports list type parameters. But point to note here is, the value passed for the parameter during log dc is not validated by the system, this could be due to keep the performance of the api intact. Always pass the right value during log as mostly the api would be used in Automation.

Hope you like the blog, do provide your feedback in the comments.

Regards,

Anil.

entry.title: Understanding Party Determination of Sales Data in Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
When it comes to managing sales in SAP Sales Cloud V2, one of the crucial processes is determining the right Sales Data whenever a sales transaction or lead is being created.

Sales Data typically includes:

  • Sales Organization
  • Distribution Channel
  • Division
  • Sales Office
  • Sales Group
  • Sales Unit

Getting these right ensures smooth order processing, pricing, reporting, and alignment of responsibility between sales reps and accounts.

Let‚Äôs break this down with a practical example.

Business Scenario: XYZ Industries

XYZ Industries is a global manufacturer of industrial equipment.

  • They sell directly to customers in some markets (B2B Distribution Channel)
  • They sell via distributors in others
  • Employees (sales reps) are often aligned with specific Sales Organizations (like ‚ÄúNorth America‚Äù or ‚ÄúEurope‚Äù), and sometimes with Sales Offices or Sales Groups (e.g., ‚ÄúWest Coast Office‚Äù or ‚ÄúDistributor Management Team‚Äù).

When a sales rep creates a new lead or opportunity in the system, the platform must automatically pick the right Sales Data. Let‚Äôs see how the system does this in steps.

Sales Data Determination

Usually Sales Data determination starts with determining the correct Sales Organization and there are determination steps available in Party Schema of Lead or Opportunities. Determination happens either from Employee Data, Organization assigned to Employee, Account Sales Data or combinations of either of them.

Employee‚Äôs Sales Data

  • The system first looks at the Sales Data maintained for the Employee.
  • If the employee has one flagged as Main, that combination of Sales Org, Distribution Channel, and Division will be selected.
  • If no main is set, the system picks any valid entry from the employee‚Äôs list of Sales Data.

Example:
John, a sales rep at XYZ Industries, has two sales data assignments:

  • North America / Direct / Equipment (marked as Main)
  • Europe / Distributor / Equipment

Since ‚ÄúNorth America / Direct / Equipment‚Äù is marked as Main, that gets picked automatically when John creates a new lead.

Intersection of Employee & Account Sales Data

  • If a step requires validating both employee and account (customer) sales data, the system finds the intersection.
  • If an intersection exists, that combination is selected.
  • If no overlap, the system skips to the next active determination step.

Example:
John is assigned to North America / Direct / Equipment.
The customer account "ABC Distributors" is maintained with North America / Direct / Equipment as valid Sales Data.

  • Intersection matches ‚Üí system picks this Sales Data.
  • If the customer only had Europe / Distributor / Equipment, there would be no intersection, so the system moves to the next step.

Sales Office & Sales Group

  • If the intersected Sales Data in the Account has Sales Office or Sales Group maintained, the system uses this detail.

Example:
If "ABC Distributors" has been linked specifically to the Los Angeles Sales Office, then when John creates a lead for them, the system will default this into the record automatically.

Organizational Assignment (Primary Employee Check)

  • If the determination step uses the Organizational Structure, the system checks where the employee is assigned as Primary.
  • If the employee is primary for a Sales Office, the system identifies which Sales Organization is tied to that office.
  • If additional restrictions (like Distribution Channel or Division) are maintained in the Sales Organization, they are also defaulted.

Example:
John is assigned as Primary Sales Rep for the Chicago Sales Office.
The Chicago Office belongs to the North America Sales Org, with restriction Direct / Equipment.

System will pick:

  • Sales Org: North America
  • Distribution Channel: Direct
  • Division: Equipment
  • Sales Office: Chicago

Why This Matters for Your Business

This determination process makes sure that:

  • Sales reps don‚Äôt waste time figuring out which sales data to use
  • Leads and opportunities always flow into the correct reporting structures
  • Customers are automatically mapped to the right sales offices and groups, ensuring accountability and accurate pipeline visibility

For large organizations like XYZ Industries, where one customer might be handled by multiple sales representatives and across different sales regions, this automation reduces errors, duplication, and admin work while improving the customer experience.

entry.title: Re: Scripting Engine - Running reports simultaneously
entry.content:
SAP GUI is not the option you want to use when considering batch or simultaneous programs.

The limitations are described here:  311440 - Batch input and controls 

Symptom

Errors occur when you process or record batch input sessions if the application uses frontend controls such as the ALV grid or tree. Typical cases:

(1)The batch input recorder does not record any actions or frontend control data.

(2) When you process batch input sessions in the background, a termination or an ABAP short dump with the exception condition CNTL_ERROR occurs. The exception condition is caused in the control framework (program SAPLOLEA or also CL_GUI_*).

(3) When you process batch input sessions in the background, a termination occurs with the message
'Editor could not be initialised' in the batch input log.
Processing a Call Transaction ... Using (processing mode N) in the background, a termination occurs with the message:
'Exception condition ERROR_DP initialized'
Since controls are only used more frequently as of Release 4.6A, these problems generally do not occur in Releases < 4.6.

Reason and Prerequisites

1. Frontend controls are generally not 

    capable of batch input. Therefore the batch input recorder does not record any data for them and they cannot be supplied with data or actions during a BI session run.
    2. Frontend controls cannot be accessed from a background process because it does not have an active SAPGUI connection. If such a communication is attempted by the application nevertheless, an exception condition is triggered by the control framework which causes a termination if it is not caught by the application.

              This also applies to the background batch input (mode E) or a Call Transaction ... Using (mode E or N or P, respectively) in dialog processing.

    3. The application uses a frontend textedit control. As with all other frontend controls, it cannot be accessed in batch input. If you try to run an application which uses this control in batch input, the system will terminate with the message BMEN 802, as for point (2). This occurs with the PFCG Transaction, for example.

Solution

 

    1.
  • If an application is to be capable of batch input, you must make sure that the desired functions can also be executed without participation of the existing frontend controls.
  • If this is not possible or cannot be achieved without investing considerable time and effort, you must use alternative methods for the data transfer (direct input, BAPIs).

 

    2.
  • If an application is running in the background or is processed in the background in dialog operation, no frontend controls may be generated and called (query on sy-batch and sy-binpt!).
  • The application developer should check whether the action that caused the termination was designed to be capable of batch input. If it was not, the batch input session must be changed accordingly. If it was, the application must make sure that no communication with frontend controls is attempted in the background or during batch input. This can be achieved with a consistent query.

 

    3. As for problem (1), the user needs to check whether another editor can be used in the application instead of the edit control. For example, the editor must be based on a step loop or table view control, so that it can also be accessed in batch input. This question will be answered by the relevant development department.


Additional information on problems (1) and (2)

  • The question that is usually asked in practice is "Can I operate a transaction in batch input if it uses frontend controls?"
  • Although the batch input cannot run actions on controls, this does not necessarily mean that you can no longer run a transaction via batch input. This would only be the case if the controls were absolutely necessary for navigating in the transaction. A particular transaction can include several simultaneous actions that can be executed via batch input and some that cannot be executed this way at all.
  • One particular problem associated with this is that batch input can allow a transaction to run in the background. In this case, the application must ensure that no controls are created and used, in order to enable batch input.


(All statements in this note also apply to applications that use fast input or CALL TRANSACTION USING.)

entry.title: Re: User-id for Concurrent employment
entry.content:
Hi @masashiyamagi74,

I hope you are keeping well.

User ID Auto-Population During Employment Details Import

Currently, it is not possible to auto-populate or overwrite user-id with a user-id generated by Business Rule when importing Employment Details via Import Employee Data, this is confirmed in the following articles.

  • 2787336 - Is it Possible to Generate User ID via Business Rule for Global assignment or Concurrent employments or Contingent Workers? - SAP for Me
  • 2678155 - Rule-based Generation of UserID/Username for Hires & Rehires with New Employment - SAP for Me

Key Limitations 

Business Rule Scope Restriction  The rule-based generation of UserID/Username through Business Rules is specifically designed for Hire and Rehire processes only, not for general data imports. The business rules are consumed directly by the Hire/Rehire Configuration object rather than standard import processes.

Import Process Behavior  During Employment Details imports:

  • If you manually provide an Assignment ID in the import file, that value takes precedence 
  • If no Assignment ID is provided, the system automatically assigns a value from the corresponding users_sys_id field.
  • The User ID generation rules configured in Hire/Rehire Configuration do not trigger during import processes 
    • Managing Mass Changes in Employee Central - Assignment ID Definition with Data Imports at: https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-employee-central/managing-mass-changes-in-employee-central/assignment-id-definition-with-data-imports?amp%3Bstate=PRODUCTION&%3Bversion=2505&locale=en-US&version=LATEST

Available Alternatives

  • Assignment ID External From release 1908, SAP introduced assignment-id-external which provides more flexibility. 
    • Can be auto-generated during import processes through Employment Settings Configuration
    • Has one-to-one mapping with userid but can be changed when required
    • Requires creating an employee settings configuration with a business rule for the "Generate Assignment ID External" scenario.
      • https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-members/mapping-employee-id-for-employee-master-replication-from-sap-successfactors/ba-p/13454046/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-members/mapping-employee-id-for-employee-master-replication-from-sap-successfactors/ba-p/13454046
  • Manual Definition  You can manually define assignment IDs in your import file templates for:
    • New employees using Basic Import template
    • Concurrent Employment using Employment Details template
    • Global Assignment using Global Assignment template

The User ID generation via Business Rules remains limited to the hiring workflow and cannot be leveraged during standard Employment Details import processes.

Auto-Generating Assignment ID External During Import
To auto-generate assignment-id-external during import in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, you need to create an Employment Settings Configuration with a business rule attached.

Configuration Steps

1. Create Employment Settings Configuration

  • Navigate to Admin Center ‚Üí Manage Data
  • Select Employment Settings Configuration from the Create New dropdown
  • Specify a code for the configuration
  • Set the Status as Active
  • Select Yes from the "Activate 'Generate Assignment ID External' by Using a Business Rule" dropdown 

2. Create Business Rule 

  • Select the Add Rule option to create a business rule
  • Ensure you create a business rule belonging to the Generate Assignment ID External scenario in the Employee Central Core rule scenario category
  • The business rule is executed during the data import process

3. Configure Rule Selection

After creating the business rule, select it from the "Rule to generate Assignment ID External" dropdown
Save the changes.

Prerequisites

HRIS Elements Configuration The required HRIS elements must be configured to add the `` field. Check the existing configuration at:  Admin Center ‚Üí Manage Business Configuration ‚Üí Employee Central ‚Üí HRIS Elements 

Import Behavior

Automatic Generation Process

  • The system generates assignment IDs while importing Employment Details or Global Assignment information
  • The assignment ID generated by the system can be different from the user ID of employees
  • Assignment ID from the import file takes precedence over the assignment ID generated by the system.

Default Behavior Without Configuration
If you don't enter an Assignment ID in the import file and no business rule is configured, the system automatically assigns a value from the corresponding ' ' field 

Supported Import Templates
This auto-generation works with:

  • Basic Import template (for new employees)
  • Employment Details template (for Concurrent Employment)
  • Global Assignment template (for Global Assignments)

The business rule execution ensures consistent assignment ID generation across all import processes while maintaining flexibility for manual overrides when needed.

  • Managing Mass Changes in Employee Central - Setting Up a Process for Auto-Generating Assignment ID at: https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-employee-central/managing-mass-changes-in-employee-central/setting-up-process-for-auto-generating-assignment-id?amp%3Bstate=PRODUCTION&%3Bversion=2505&locale=en-US&version=LATEST
  • Managing Mass Changes in Employee Central - Assignment ID Definition with Data Imports at: https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-employee-central/managing-mass-changes-in-employee-central/assignment-id-definition-with-data-imports?amp%3Bstate=PRODUCTION&%3Bversion=2505&locale=en-US&version=LATEST

Hope this helps

All the best

entry.title: Re: Inventory Count - Posting only possible in periods 20...
entry.content:
Hello @Phil_P 

You are correct; after closing the Materials Management (MM) period, posting backdated inventory differences into that month is no longer allowed.

Regarding your question about the next time:

  • If the MM period is still open, you can post inventory counts with a posting date in the previous month, for example, 28.08. The system will accept it because the August period remains open.
  • Once the period is closed, postings can only be made within the currently open period, for example, September. In such cases, the posting date must be adjusted to fall within the open period.

So, the timing of the period close is crucial: backdating is only effective while that MM period remains open.

With regards
Chuma

entry.title: Authorization Profiles
entry.content:
Hi ABAP experts.

I am creating an ABAP program to do a mass update of roles, rather than manually doing it with transaction PFCG.  I am removing manually-added T-Codes, then adding them to the Role Menu as Authorization Default using method CL_PFCG_MENU_MODIFY->MENU_ADD_SERVICE.  This works well, changing the AGR_1251-MODIFIED field from 'U' to 'S',  However, when the Authorization Profile is generated using PRGN_AUTO_GENERATE_PROFILE_NEW, it also brings in a lot of unwanted authorizations, such as SE16 bringing in S_TABU_DIS and S_TABU_NAM. 

The method CL_PFCG_MENU_MODIFY->MENU_DELETE_NODE will remove them, but they will come back whenever the profile is regenerated.

The solution is to set the Authorization as 'Inactive', but I cannot find a Method or Function Module that will do this.  I tried doing a direct table update (which is not recommended) to AGR_1251, setting the DELETED field to 'X'.  When I do this and look at the role in PFCG and in table AGR_1251, it appears to have worked.  When someone logs into the system with that role, executes SE16, they should not be able to select any table to display.  However, even though the Authorizations are Inactive, they can still display table contents.

Can someone please help me out with how to achieve my goal?

entry.title: Bringing Clarity to 360-Degree Feedback process with SAP SuccessFactors‚Äô AI-Driven Innovations
entry.content:
Implementing a 360-degree feedback program is a smart move for many companies looking to help their employees grow and become better leaders. Getting feedback from different people is definitely valuable‚Äîbut turning that feedback into something more clear, helpful and easy to understand can still be a challenge. In recent conversations with customer and partners, who are exploring or implementing SAP SuccessFactors 360 Degree Multi-Rater Reviews as part of their talent strategy, several key insights have emerged. These takeaways may be valuable for organizations moving from a third-party feedback tool or looking to enhance the impact of their existing programs. Since many of these questions come up often in discussions, I‚Äôve put this blog together to share what we‚Äôre hearing and learning.

Here are the questions I‚Äôve recently been reviewing - Can the system generate comprehensive and user-friendly reports? Will it support tailored feedback across different leadership levels? And how can it leverage emerging technologies like AI to make feedback easier to interpret and act upon? This blog explores these questions, highlighting common expectations around 360-degree feedback reporting, the capabilities within SAP SuccessFactors, and how Artificial Intelligence (AI) is shaping the future of multi-rater feedback.

Understanding the Need for Tailored 360-degree Feedback Reports

One of the key parts of a successful 360-degree feedback process is to be able to adjust reports for different roles and levels of the person getting the feedback. Many organizations group their audiences by variables like, seniority and job responsibilities‚Äîoften creating different reports for senior leaders, people managers, and team members.

This kind of role-based setup helps make sure the feedback is meaningful and supports their specific growth goals. Each group needs a different feedback experience that reflects their unique responsibilities and development needs. This separation ensures the feedback is relevant and that reports are intuitive for the respective audience. Each audience expects that the feedback is presented in a way that is both insightful and accessible, with reports designed to include clear summaries, actionable visuals, and minimal interpretation needed from HR or managers.

One common design goal is to make the report self-explanatory, so the recipient can read and understand it directly‚Äîwithout needing someone else to interpret the results. This is especially important in organizations aiming to scale their 360 program or support distributed teams.

Core Reporting Expectations for 360 Reviews

Organizations often look for the following features in their 360 feedback reports:

  1. Participation Tracking and Management
    The system should provide a clear summary of who has completed their assessments and allow administrators to send reminders when needed.
  2. Competency Ratings and Gap Analysis
    Reports should show average ratings for competencies or behaviors, segmented by rater category (e.g., peers, managers, direct reports). They should also allow comparisons between self-ratings and those from others to highlight gaps, helping identify potential blind spots or over-/under-estimations.
  3. Strengths and Development Areas
    Reports should highlight top and low-rated competencies or behaviors to help recipients quickly see their strengths and areas for improvement, supporting more focused development planning.
  4. Comments and Qualitative Feedback
    Including open-ended comments from raters add depth to the numerical ratings and provides actionable insights.
  5. Integration with Development Planning
    Feedback should seamlessly connect with individual development goals, supporting ongoing growth beyond the review cycle.
  6. Flexibility and Customization
    The reporting tool should allow organizations to choose which raters to compare and how data is presented, tailoring the experience to specific business needs.

How SAP SuccessFactors Meets and Exceeds These Expectations

The Detailed 360 Reports available within SAP SuccessFactors are designed to meet these core requirements with a high degree of flexibility. It lets you combine self-feedback with anonymous input from colleagues and external sources, giving you a complete and well-rounded view of employee performance across your organization.

Disclaimer: All images used in the following sections are for representational purpose only.

The Participation Summary mirrors common evaluation summaries by tracking response completion and enabling action such as reminders and recall.

Competency ratings are shown not just as overall averages but broken down by rater groups, giving a clearer picture of different perspectives.

The Gap Analysis or comparison views allow users to select which rater categories to compare, offering more customizations.

Rank views highlight highest and lowest-rated competencies, helping recipients focus attention effectively.

The Hidden Strengths and Blind Spots view pinpoints significant differences between self and other ratings, revealing perception gaps.

Comments are organized by competency and rater group, making it easier to review qualitative insights.

The Development Goal is fully integrated, enabling users to create and monitor goals directly linked to feedback results.

These capabilities give organizations the tools to create customized, detailed reports that meet their specific feedback and development needs.

The Role of AI in Enhancing SAP SuccessFactors 360-Degree Feedback

Looking beyond current features, SAP SuccessFactors 360 Degree Multi-Rater Reviews is leveraging Generative AI (GenAI) to transform how organizations collect, interpret, and act on 360 feedback, such as:

AI-Generated Summaries:
Instead of manually reading through numerous comments, AI can summarize key themes and insights to generate the summary of detailed 360 Report, including feedback on specific attributes such as skills or competencies, reducing the time needed to interpret feedback.

Sentiment and Tone Analysis:
SAP‚Äôs 360 Reviews includes AI tools that can detect the emotional tone of feedback, helping identify feelings like praise or frustration that may not be clear from ratings alone. You can run sentiment analysis on comments for specific skills or competencies to understand how raters feel about an employee‚Äôs performance. The tool reviews the comment, skill name, and other details to tag the feedback as positive, negative, mixed, or unknown.

Bias Detection:
The AI-assisted writing tool in SAP SuccessFactors‚Äô 360 Degree feedback helps employees improve their writing when giving feedback. AI can also help make feedback fairer by flagging biased or unclear language and encouraging reviewers to write clearer, more constructive comments. This tool suggests better grammar, spelling, and word choices, while ensuring the tone fits the audience‚Äîwhether professional or friendly. It can help users write more clearly and briefly, change paragraphs into bullet points, and offer helpful tips based on the task they‚Äôre doing in the system.

Actionable Insights:
Assisted 360 Review feature provides suggestions for improvement by identifying areas where employees can grow and offering actionable recommendations. These insights help guide upskilling, career development, and personalized next steps based on the feedback received. There are more features that are being discussed, for example, to be able to include direct link to create a development goal from the insights.

These advancements aim not to replace human judgment but to support managers and employees in making sense of complex feedback data and turning it into meaningful growth opportunities.

Core requirements to enable and use AI features in 360-degree reviews are:

  • The fundamental license required for 360-degree feature is for the SAP SuccessFactors Performance and Goals module.
  • AI-generated insights on 360 reports are considered a premium and require a separate license for SAP AI Units.
  • Administrators to have the Administrator->Manage AI Capabilities->AI Services Administration permission in Role based permission configurations.
  • Users have the User Permissions->AI Access->Assisted Writing permission to use AI Assisted Writing feature.
  • For additional details, please follow implementation guide - SAP Help ‚Äì SuccessFactors 360 Reviews.

Final Thoughts: Collaboration and Clarity Are Key

Implementing 360-degree feedback successfully requires clear alignment between HR teams, technology partners, and stakeholders. It is essential to:

  • Define the key audiences and tailor the feedback experience accordingly
  • Set expectations around report design, usability, and actionability
  • Leverage expert guidance to ensure the technology meets organizational needs
  • Explore AI-driven features thoughtfully to amplify the value of feedback

SAP SuccessFactors offers a robust 360 Review solution that can accommodate diverse use cases, provide flexible and intuitive reporting, and increasingly incorporate AI to enhance insights.

For organizations planning or refining their 360 feedback programs, a deep understanding of these capabilities and careful planning can make all the difference between collecting feedback and creating a true culture of continuous development.

SAP Help ‚Äì SuccessFactors 360 Reviews

SAP Help ‚Äì Premium AI Features in SAP SuccessFactors  

Learning Journey ‚Äì 360 Reviews

I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts‚Äîfeel free to share your comments, insights, or experiences.

entry.title: IP Details Request
entry.content:
We need to whitelist the SAP Commerce Cloud endpoints; please advise how to access this information in the Cloud Portal.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: IP Details Request
entry.content:
Hello!

To retrieve this information from Cloud Portal one should follow the steps below:

  1. Open Cloud Portal home page
  2. Go to environment details page of the Commerce Cloud environment, for which public IP address must be obtained
  3. Click on any endpoint's name, what will open "Edit Endpoint" page (also known as endpoint details page).
  4. The public IP address will displayed in the web proxy field located in the General Information section.

NOTE: Please be aware that public IP address of a SAP Commerce Cloud is the same for all public endpoints within one particular environment.

More details are present in KBA 3302662 - How to Check SAP Commerce Cloud's IPs and IP Range. 
Please let me know in case you need further assistance on the topic. 

Best regards,
Stephane
SAP Support

entry.title: Creating your first IFlow in Cloud Integration for an IBP - S/4HANA (on prem/private) integration
entry.content:
Hi Community,

 

Continuing this blog series on working with Cloud Integration  from  SAP BTP's SAP Integration Suite service.
We will cover in this article how to create and deploy your first customer integration flow between SAP Integrated Business Planning and SAP S/4HANA (on premise / private cloud).

 

Prerequisites

  • All steps from my previous two blog entries BTP/IBP Technical setup and Integration Suite Initial Configuration.
  • Users have been created via the BTP cockpit with the relevant roles depending on what tasks they need to perform. The three typical roles for CI are the following: PI_Administrator, PI_Integration_Developer and PI_Business_Expert. Check the Personas for CI information to understand what each covers in order to assign the most relevant ones.
    • To support actions from this blog entry you need the PI_Integration_Developer role.
  • The SAP S/4HANA, Supply Chain Integration Add-On for SAP Integrated Business Planning is configured in S/4HANA for integration purposes.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 

Creating your customer iflow

Now that we have done the technical setup and configured Integration Suite to define source/target systems (called destinations) and loaded the reusable iflows we can start building our own project integrations: customer iflows.

To begin, we can start creating a simple business iflow that calls upon a reusable iflow delivered with the August 2025 release called Generic Data Transfer.

The latter is a full-fledged iflow that is built on the basis on a series of individual reusable iflows (that cannot be executed as standalone). It can be leveraged to : read the S/4HANA integration addon extractors, transform & map data to corresponding IBP target and load it there (triggering the IBP post processing batch).

 

 

But if you want to call upon it with two different sets of parameters, i.e. calling two different extractors with corresponding filters to send POs AND PlannedOrders to IBP, then you have to have two customer iflows. It is the same in CI-DS : for two key figure objects you need two dataflows or even two tasks.

So we can create a first customer iflow that simply calls our Generic Data Transfer iflow as a model that we‚Äôll later copy as many times as needed to cover each object we need to send to IBP. We call this model a wrapper.

 

Access your Integration Suite tenant and the Design > Integrations and APIs section from your left side panel.

Click on Create and fill out the needed information to set your own package.

Think of your package as a project in CIDS, a grouping of iflows that you could attach significance to (e.g. a package per source system or type of data integrated or target planning area, etc.). You can also store documents (e.g. specifications, guides, etc.) in your package to support integration activities.

Click on Add > Integration Flow

A blank canvas appears with the premises of your flow.

At the top, you have various features allowing you to build your flow. Our intend here is to have one prior step, before adding a call to our main reusable iflow, called a content modifier. This object will allow us to define and pass along global parameter values to the generic reusable iflow in order to send specific data to IBP, e.g. purchase orders.

From the menu, select Transformation > Content Modifier

Click in the middle of the process structure to add it between the start and end events. Bring up the details section of the Content Modifier from the bottom of the screen and define a name for this step.

 

A process must begin and end with events. For our purpose, let‚Äôs use a timer as a start event. Select from the upper functions Event > Timer.

 

Place it before our previous Content Modifier and delete the preexisting Start event.

 

You can choose how the timer start works by clicking on it and updating its properties from the bottom of the screen. Go to tab Scheduler and select Basic with the below selections so that the execution of ths iflow only starts when you manually trigger its deployment.

 

This is how you can also schedule your iflow to run with more frequency, for example every day/week, etc (see the Repeat criteria above) or with more complex modes (see the Advanced tab). Once you have set this, you need to save your iflow:

 

 

To remove the preexisting Start event, click on it and then on the bin icon that appears to its right

You can proceed the same way with the Sender /Receiver objects to the left and right of the flow.

Next, we need to add our generic reusable iflow that encodes calls to both S/4HANA and IBP. For this, you can again look for the upper function Call > External Call > Request Reply or click on the previous process step, the Content Modifier, and select the ‚Äúadd flow step‚Äù  option via the ‚Äú+‚Äù icon.

Select request reply

Add it to the right of the Content Modifier, before the end event and give it a name.

This step will technically call the generic reusable iflow. To do this we will add a Receiver in the iflow definition.

search for Receiver and add it to the flow. 

 

Note you can also add it from the upper function Participant > Receiver.

The system now asks how you want to link the Request Reply to the Receiver by choosing from a list of adapter types. Select Process Direct to specify you need to call another process (the generic reusable iflow).

The Receiver is placed outside of the integration process box, you can also rename it to better understand its use by simply clicking on the box and changing its properties.

Now to link this external call to the generic reusable iflow, you need to click on the Process Direct arrow linking the two objects and look to the ‚ÄúConnection‚Äù tab of its properties, set the full technical ID of the reusable iflow in the Address field:

  • SAP_IBP_Add-on_Read_-_Generic_Process

Note: you can find this ID by navigating to the reusable iflow itself : Design section from the left side panel, select the ‚ÄúSAP IBP Add-On - Reusable Integration Flows‚Äù package, open the iflow ‚ÄúSAP IBP Add-On Read - Generic Data Transfer‚Äù. Bring up the flow properties from the bottom of the screen and find its ID.

Our customer iflow now has all necessary objects to run (the wrapper being a quick set up), we just need to define the global parameters for the Content Modifier we created as a first step in order to have the possibility during execution of the flow to specify what extractor should be read, what mapping should be applied, what filters should be used, etc.

These parameters are already part of the reusable iflow so once we call them in the first step and fill them, they will be automatically read and applied.

To be able to set your own values when executing (deploying) the iflow, you need to externalize them via the Content Modifier step this way:

Click on your Content Modifier step, previously named Set Extraction Filters and click on Externalize from its properties section.

Create your parameters one by one (use the Add button to allow entering more parameters).

  • Type the parameter name in the Name column from the below table:

Non exhaustive list of available global parameters

Parameter Name

Description

FileName

Name of the generated file passed to IBP that you can download from the Data Integration Jobs app.

TypeOfData

The type of data to load, KeyFigures or MasterData (respect this way of writing).

TimeDisaggregationLevel

Use time level values that are defined in the time profile of the planning area in IBP using the Planning Areas ‚Äì Model Configuration app.

You can only specify a TimeDisaggregationLevel value that is the same or higher than the base time profile level of the planning level you‚Äôre uploading data to. If TimeDisaggregationLevel is left empty, it defaults to the base time profile level.

MasterDataType

The target Master Data type you want to load in IBP without the prefix that is usually used to distinguish master data types for different planning areas.

Example: your master data type is ABCPRODUCT, type in PRODUCT here.

MasterDataPrefix

Here you can set the prefix only.

Example: your master data type is ABCPRODUCT, type in ABC here.

BatchName

The name that appears as batch in the Data Integration Jobs app in IBP.

PostFetchFilterExtensionID

If you are using an extension for defining filters, this is where you‚Äôd set its ID. Will be covered in a future blog entry.

ERPMaxPackageSize

Maximum package size coming from the S/4HANA integration addon for IBP.

MappingExtensionID

If you are using an extension for mapping, this is where you‚Äôd set its ID. Will be covered in a future blog entry.

Extractor

The S/4HANA extractor ID to use as data source.

ERPRequestedFields

Source fields to map from S/4HANA side. Add them in any order, separated by commas.

Example : PRDID,LOCID,KEYFIGUREDATE,PLANNINGRELEVQTY

IBPFieldList

Target fields to map to IBP. Add them in any order, separated by commas.

Example : PRDID,LOCID,KEYFIGUREDATE,MINRECEIPT

FieldMap

Mapping between above S/4HANA and IBP fields.

Separate mapping groups by commas and separate source from target with colons.

Example : PRDID: PRDID,LOCID: LOCID, KEYFIGUREDATE: KEYFIGUREDATE,PLANNINGRELEVQTY:MINRECEIPT

Note: when both source and target have the same ID, you do not need to add them here, so the simplified version of the mapping in the above case that would also work is :

PLANNINGRELEVQTY:MINRECEIPT

DestinationforSAPIBP

The Destination configured in BTP cockpit to represent the IBP tenant you want to use as target for the flow.

PlanningArea

The IBP planning area as target for the flow.

PlanningAreaVersion

The IBP planning area version as target for the flow.

Filters

Defines the filter criteria in restricted OData format:

‚Ä¢ Relational operators

These operators are EQ, NE, LT, LE, GT, GE, and LIKE.

‚Ä¢ Logical operators

These operators are AND, NOT, OR, (, and ).

‚Ä¢ Functions

These functions are STARTSWITH, ENDSWITH, and SUBSTRINGOF.

Separate the conditions by a comma. The objects you filter on are fields from the S/4HANA extractor.

Example: TIMEPROFILEID EQ '2504',TIMEPROFILELEVEL EQ '2',MRPELEMENTTYPE EQ 'BE'

ERPDestination

The Destination configured in BTP cockpit to represent the S/4HANA tenant you want to use as source for the flow.

ProcessUnchangedData

If you want to skip unchanged data, regardless of SAP IBP

global parameter setting for this behavior, set this parameter to false. If you want to process unchanged data, regardless of the SAP IBP global parameter setting, set this parameter to true. If you leave this parameter field empty, the SAP IBP global parameter determines the behavior.

BatchCommand

Defines the operation type. Accepted parameters are:

INSERT_UPDATE, REPLACE, DELETE.

 

  • Leave the Source type as Constant.
  • The Source Value allows you to either
    • give a default value that will not be modifiable when deploying the iflow,
    • give a default value that the user can update upon deployment,
    • set no value and let the user define it during deployment.

 

To set a default value that will not be editable by the user when deploying the iflow, simply fill in the Source Value field with your value.

Example: you want this iflow to always be executed in Insert/update load mode in IBP.

 

To let the user define the value only upon deploying the iflow, fill in the Source Value field with the name of the parameter surrounded by double brackets on each side (format {{FileName}}). Once you validate, this will appear as < Define Value >.

When you validate:


And finally, to set a default value that can be editable when deploying the iflow, proceed as above with the double brackets strategy and then click on the < Define Value> value. This opens a new window where you can set your default value.

Example: you want your iflow to be used for loading Key Figures by default but if a user needs to change this to send Master Data, they can make that change during deployment.

 

In the end, you have set all global parameters that impacts the way the integration is executed, click on OK.

Then Save.

 

The configuration of your customer iflow as a wrapper of an end to end reusable iflow is finished, we can now deploy it!

 

Deploying your customer iflow

So now we have a customer iflow that :

  • Starts when deployed (manually / via schedule)
  • Expects input global parameters to identify systems, extractor name, filters to apply, mapping, etc.
  • Uses a pre configured reusable iflow that opens connections to source and target systems, reads S/4HANA data, loads data in IBP and triggers post processing there.

To deploy your customer iflow, access it from your package, click on the menu and select Configure to set your final parameters and deploy.

If you Deploy without the configuration, the iflow will use all your defaulted global parameter values directly.

You can here adapt your global parameters if needed, then click on Deploy

Validate the runtime profile as CI by clicking on Yes.

Check the log in the Monitor section of the left side panel. Go to Monitor Message Processing app.

Find your iflow name and select the associated entry

 

Note that in CI you will get individual log entries for each iflow and embedded iflow. This means since we are using a wrapper iflow that calls upon a reusable iflow, itself calling upon individual reusable iflows, you will get multiple entries for your single deployment action.

To identify all logs related to your deployment, you can use the Correlation ID associated to the initial entry associated to your customer iflow entry. Click on the hyperlink, this will copy this value to the header filter and only show you log entries related to your deployment action. You can appreciate all steps executed during this deployment.

Note : when analyzing log issues (will be handled via an example in another blog entry), always start from the last log entry and make your way upwards one by one.

 

Finally, once you‚Äôve checked your flow was successful, you can proceed to the target system, IBP, to confirm post processing. Access the Data Integration Jobs app from your IBP tenant and check logs.

 

That‚Äôs it ! you‚Äôve created and executed your first customer iflow in CI from S/4HANA to IBP !

 

Creating customer iflows per IBP object

Now that you‚Äôve successfully created a reference iflow, you can duplicate it as many times as needed and only make changes to the global parameters in order to create integration for all the necessary IBP objects for both key figures (purchase orders, production orders, sales orders & deliveries, actuals, stock,‚Ä¶) and master data (products, locations, PDS, etc.) that are supported by the S/4HANA integration addon for IBP.

You can select your primary customer iflow from the Design section and from its menu, select Copy

 

Give a name to your new iflows identifying what data they are integrating.

For each, access the menu and select Configure. Replace mappings, filters, extractor names, etc. to adjust to the data needed.

Example for the Production Orders iflow:

Click on Save. Do this for each iflow to set up your whole interfaces from S/4HANA to IBP and schedule them accordingly at a later stage as shown previously.

 

You can also copy this iflow to use for master data transfer. Make sure in that case that aside from updating the extractor name, mappings, filters, you also set the TypeOfData parameter to ‚ÄòMasterData‚Äô and that you properly fill out the MasterDataType and MasterDataPrefix parameters.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Next blog entries will deal with:

  • Tips and tricks on working the Monitor section
  • Special case handling in Mapping (including mapping extensions)
  • Special case handling in Filtering (including filter extensions)

 

Sources

  • SAP IBP Help on S/4HANA integration to IBP via CI
  • IBP Reusable integration flows - list and details

entry.title: Guidance on Assignment Profile Updates for Revised Item
entry.content:
Hi,

I‚Äôve revised a free-floating item that is assigned via an assignment profile. During the revision process, I opted to update all learning plans impacted by the change, and the new version has successfully replaced the old one in existing plans.

To ensure future assignments use the latest version without triggering notifications, should I update the assignment profile to include the new item revision, or can I retain the old version on the assignment profile and set the new version as a substitute to the old version?

My goal is for both current and future assignments to reflect the updated course version, while avoiding user notifications. The system is configured to notify users only of new learning assignments. However, replacing the old item with the new one in the assignment profile appears to trigger such notifications.

Previously, I disabled the learning plan notification job before making changes, then re-enabled it afterward, but notifications were still sent. Is there a recommended approach to prevent this?

Please vote for the ability to disable the learning plan notification as part of the revision process as well as having an option in the assignment profile to disable the learning plan notification.

Improvement Request Details - Customer Influence

Thank you,
Susan

entry.title: Re: Country dimension for Expense Reporting not working f...
entry.content:
Hello @VirendraSharmaFICO 

What you‚Äôre observing is expected in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition today

The insurance details, such as Customer Country/Region, are supplied for analytical purposes. They are integrated into reports via data source extensions but are not accessible as input or target fields in Create Supplier Invoice, Manage Concur Substitution Rules, or Asset Posting substitutions. Therefore, they cannot be populated during AP entry, import into Concur, or depreciation processes run. SAP Help Portal-Add Dimensions to the Analytical Apps Using Data Source Extensions

Practical options supporthe ted by cloud

Put a country value on the FI document (ACDOCA):

  • Create a custom field for the Journal Entry, Item in Custom Fields and Logic. Be sure to enable it for Create Supplier Invoice, Advanced, and other relevant options to ensure everything works smoothly reporting. SAP Help Portal-App Extensibility: Create Supplier Invoice - Advanced
  • Map Concur‚Äôs country into the custom field, following the SAP‚Äôs Concur‚ÜíS/4 journal extension pattern. SAP Community-Extending Journal Content and Structure with SAP Concur Expense Data

If you only need analytics:

  • Keep the country in concur and include it in analytics (SAC/embedded) with the journal lines, or display the insurance dimensions in GL reports via data source extensions. SAP Help Portal-Add Dimensions to the Analytical Apps Using Data Source Extensions

For Fixed Assets/depreciation:

  • You cannot replace a standard ‚Äúcountry‚Äù target in this context today. If you require expenses broken down by country, use Universal Allocation (in the Margin Analysis or Manage Allocations section) to allocate or split costs by country at the end of the period into dedicated accounts or characteristics. SAP Help Portal-Universal Allocation

Product gap:

  • If you require the standard Country/Region dimension to be writeable in AP/Concur/FA flows, submit a request via SAP Continuous Influence. SAP Community-Finance in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2402

The standard insurance dimensions are mainly for reporting. To track expenses by country in FI now, you can use a custom JE item field combined with Concur mapping, or you can calculate it at the end of the period using Universal Allocation.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud Application Studio 2508 installation
entry.content:
Dear Charles,

SAP has deprecated the Pilot installer and aligned the SDK with Visual Studio 2022 (Professional or Enterprise editions).
This ensures a modern, supported development environment and better integration with current .NET frameworks.

How to Resolve the Issue

Follow these steps to move from the Pilot version to the supported setup:

1. Install Visual Studio 2022

Get a licensed copy of Visual Studio 2022 Professional or Enterprise.

Either edition will work ‚Äî Community edition is not supported.

2. Download the SAP Extension (VSIX)

  1. Go to the SAP Software Download Center.
  2. Download the latest VSIX extension matching your SDK release (e.g., 2508).
  3. Close all open Visual Studio instances.
  4. Double-click the .vsix file to install.

3. Connect to Your Tenant

  1. Open Visual Studio 2022.
  2. On the start page, select ‚ÄúContinue without code.‚Äù
  3. Navigate to View ‚Üí My Solutions / Implementation Manager.
  4. Click Log On and enter your ByDesign system URL, User ID, and Password.

4. Fix Common Errors

If you see a .NET Framework error, install .NET Framework 4.8 and restart Visual Studio.

Note that the layout is slightly different from Visual Studio 2015, but the core functions (like creating patches) are still there.

5. Continue Development

Load your solution.

From the Implementation Manager, choose Create Patch or perform any other development activity.

You‚Äôre now ready to continue working in the new environment.

Key Takeaways:

The Pilot SDK is no longer supported after release 2508.
You must use Visual Studio 2022 (Professional or Enterprise) + the latest SAP VSIX extension.
.NET Framework 4.8 may be required for compatibility.

Once set up, you can log in, connect to your repository, and continue development as usual.

Regards,
Tiago
SAP ByD Technical Support

entry.title: Re: How to Remove user from Universal ID? Is it possible...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Now it's possible for customer to unlink user from UID on customer side via self-service. Kindly refer to the detailed steps introduced in KBA 3619621.

As mentioned in the KBA, customer can unlink a user from an SAP Universal ID via Self-Service ONLY when multiple users are linked to an SAP Universal ID.

If a user is the sole individual associated with the SAP Universal ID, the "Unlink Identity" option will not be available, and only SAP Support can perform the unlinking.

For detailed instructions on how to request the unlinking of a user, refer to KBA 2914815.

Hope the above information helps.

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Prioritization of the Supplier Bank Accounts
entry.content:
Hello,

Currently, multiple IBANs can be stored for a vendor. Now, in practice, it happens that the supplier communicates new bank details.
In the payment proposal list in the selection "Payments in Preparation", the system always proposes the highest IBAN from the supplier master data.
Only by manually comparing the IBAN specified on the invoice can you determine that the IBAN proposed by SAP is incorrect.
The payment number must be opened and other bank details must be selected manually.

In this example, SAP uses the IBAN XYZ... instead of the new bank details ABC... from the second Propose line for payment.

Question: Is it possible to choose one of the bank details as main details or to change the priority somehow? Maybe we could sort that by "valid from" and set it to use it in the payment process?
Our goal is to propose the last bank details stored in the supplier master data in the payment process.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Prioritization of the Supplier Bank Accounts
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

Currently the system does not automatically select based on "valid from" or the date of creation. By default, the system uses the bank account with the highest internal sequence number (or technically the "last one read" according to internal logic). That‚Äôs why you see the "highest IBAN" being proposed.

The payment proposal will only use another bank account if:

  • A specific bank account is referenced in the supplier invoice (field ‚ÄúHouse Bank‚Äù / ‚ÄúSupplier Bank Details‚Äù), or

  • You manually change it in the payment proposal before execution.

We also have a few KBAs that could guide you in similar scenarios:

1989250- Supplier Bank Account not Proposed Correctly in the Automatic Payment https://me.sap.com/notes/1989250

2608383- The Bank Accounts Are Not Proposed Correctly During Automatic Payments https://me.sap.com/notes/2608383

1522315- The Bank Accounts Are Not Proposed Correctly During Automatic Payments https://me.sap.com/notes/1522315

 

Best regards,  

Ihan

entry.title: Cloud BAdI to Update Sales Order in Finalize Phase
entry.content:
Cloud BAdI to Update Sales Order in Finalize Phase

As I explained in blog Sales Document BAdI Overview, there are limited sales document fields can be modified via custom logic in BAdI due to various reasons. On the other hand, we are receiving customer requirements to update sales document standard fields via custom logic to control standard business processes. It is a journey to enhance extensibility in sales document processes to better fulfill business requirements. 

Here I am happy to announce a new Cloud BAdI will be introduced in CE2508 which allows customers to modify custom fields and certain standard fields in sales document finalize phase before save. Please find detail information in https://api.sap.com/badi/SD_SLS_FINALIZE.

Why New BAdI?

As there are already many Cloud BAdIs available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, I am often asked why a new BAdI should be introduced rather than reusing existing ones. Here are some considerations we received from customers and partners regarding our existing Cloud BAdIs:

  • In transactional BAdIs like SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD or SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM, customer can only access partial sales document information. For example, customers cannot access schedule line data from BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD. If a customer wants to use schedule line data to update custom field at the sales document header level, this cannot be achieved by implementing custom logic in BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD. 
  • The BAdI import parameter is not stable and reliable in transactional BAdIs like SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD or SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM, as these BAdIs are called multiple times during sales document processing. 
  • In automatic channels that do not involve user interaction, transactional BAdIs are not the best option for influencing the sales document process. Instead, the BAdIs that are processed only once during document saving are more suitable for handling such use cases. For example, the SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE BAdI is only called during the save process. 
  • The BAdI import parameter is more stable in finalize phase BAdIs like SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE, and all sales document entities are accessible via this BAdI. However, it is not possible to update any sales document data in this BAdI as it was was only defined to check the sales document before saving. 

Definition of New Cloud BAdI

To address the demands from customers and partners, a new BAdI, SD_SLS_FINALIZE, has been introduced to update the sales document data during the finalize phase before save. This new Cloud BAdI has following aspects:

  • The import parameters are more reliable because this BAdI is processed during sales document save phase
  • All sales document entities are accessible through this BAdI 
  • Custom fields on both sales document header and item can be modified via this BAdI
  • Certain standard fields can be modified via this BAdI, such as the rejection reason code at the line item level

Let's take a closer look at the details of new Cloud BAdI SD_SLS_FINALIZE. 

BAdI Parameters

Following import parameters are defined in this BAdI so that customer can access those entities:

  • sales document header
  • sales document header partners
  • sales document items
  • sales document item partners
  • sales document schedule lines

Following changing parameters are defined in this BAdI so that customer can modify sales document data:

  • custom fields on sales document header level
  • custom fields on sales document item level
  • rejection reason code on sales document item
  • control fields to indicate what field is modified 

Business Example 

I'd like to use a business example to explain how this BAdI fulfills a business requirement. 

Supplier company XYZ sells products to different customers via portal. When customers place orders in the supplier portal, the OData API is called to create sales orders. The order creation process in supplier company XYZ is fully automatic. Only in exceptional cases sales experts will manually operate the sales order through the sales order UI. 

Due to fluctuations in the prices of raw materials, company XYZ generally does not accept customer orders with long-term delivery requests. To ensure financial risk is under control, system shall automatically reject customer orders requested to be delivered later than 1 month.  

Solution via Extensibility

The sales document finalize BAdI is the best option to handle this use case, as the finalize BAdI SD_SLS_FINALIZE works across all sales document processing channels. It is ideally suited for handling the automatic order creation scenario from supplier company XYZ. 

Define Reject Reason Code

Go to SSCUI 102494 to define a new rejection reason code for long-term delivery request. 

This reject reason code will be used in the BAdI implementation when customer requested delivery date is in 30 days away. 

BAdI Implementation

Open the app "Custom Logic" and create a BAdI implementation for BAdI SD_SLS_FINALIZE.

Implement following ABAP code and then publish the BAdI implementation. 

* Set the rejection reason to sales order item when customer requested delivery date is
* 30 days away
  if salesdocument-salesdocumenttype = 'TA' and salesdocument-salesorganization = '1010'.
    "check is customer requested delivery date is more than 30 days from today
    if salesdocument-requesteddeliverydate - salesdocument-creationdate > 30.
      loop at salesdocumentitems_change assigning field-symbol(<ls_item_change>).
        <ls_item_change>-salesdocumentrjcnreason = 'Z1'.
        <ls_item_change>-control-salesdocumentrjcnreason = abap_true.
      endloop.
    endif.
  endif.

Test Sales Order via UI

Create a sales order in Fiori application and set the requested delivery date within 30 days. 

Add the item and save the order. System shows nothing is rejected.

Create a new sales order and set the requested delivery date in November. 

Add items and save the sales order. 

After the sales order is saved, both sales order items are rejected with the rejection reason code 'Z1' which was set in BAdI implementation logic.

Go to status view and system indicates all items are rejected.

Test Order Creation via OData API

Call sales order A2X OData API to create a sales order. In the OData API payload, the requested delivery date is set on September 10th which is within 30 days period. 

The sales order 23311 is created via OData call. Go to system to check if line item is rejected in this sales order. 

Then create a new sales order via OData API call, and set the requested delivery to November 10th which is out of 30 days period. 

Open the sales order 23313 and check if line item is rejected automatically. 

Test Order Simulation via OData API

Order simulation via API call is also important for customer's business scenario. Since the sales document finalize BAdI is called in all sales document processing channels, using custom logic to reject line item in order simulation is also possible. 

Call sales order A2X OData simulation API to simulate the order creation and set the requested delivery date to November 10th which is out of 30 days period.

Check the OData simulation response in the right panel, the sales document item rejection fields are updated based on BAdI logic. 

Moving Forward

The sales document finalize BAdI will be helpful in fulfilling various business use cases to influence sales document processes. Currently, this BAdI is only available for sales orders and sales orders without charge. 

In the future, based on customer requirements, this BAdI will be enhanced to support more sales document types and allow the modification of additional standard fields. Please feel free to submit your requirement through the Customer Influence Portal to help us prioritize our product roadmap.

  • he reduction of working time (RTT) is a system that provides allocation of days whose working time exceeds 35 hours per week.
  • Fix the number of days for the year (package)
  • The number of RTT days is set by company agreement. The agreement also sets the conditions for acquisition
  • public holiday on normal working days in 202330 days vacation.
  • 105 Saturday and Sunday in 2023

Calculation

Total working days in 2023:  221

Fixed total working day 213 as per company agreement

In 2023, 221 ‚Äì 213 = 8 days RTT

The employee will have a quota of 8 days to be consumed between 01/01/2023and 31/12/2023
